item.title: Lou Cannon Dies at 92; Journalist Chronicled Reagan as an Author
item.description: He was a foremost authority on the president, tracing his career in unvarnished accounts from his time as California governor through his years in the White House.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden

item.title: Mangione’s Lawyers Take Issue With Bondi’s Ties to UnitedHealthcare
item.description: Lawyers for Luigi Mangione, who is accused of killing UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive, say Attorney General Pam Bondi should have recused herself from the case.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Attorney General Pam Bondi recently worked for a lobbying firm that lists UnitedHealthcare’s parent company among its clients.

item.title: ‘Where’s the Humanity?’ Bondi Attack Leaves Suspects’ Neighborhood Stunned
item.description: ‘Where’s the Humanity?’ Bondi Attack Leaves Suspects’ Neighborhood Stunned

media:content.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times

item.title: Two NJ Transit Trains Collide, Injuring More Than a Dozen People
item.description: The incident Friday evening shut down the Montclair-Boonton Line in Montclair, N.J.
item.dc:creator: Camille Baker

item.title: Sudanese Refugees Describe Their Escape From Darfur
item.description: No one knows the true toll of the massacre, and the city remains isolated. Now, refugee camps in Chad are flooded with newly displaced Sudanese.
item.dc:creator: Ivor Prickett
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

media:content.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: Corrections: Dec. 20, 2025
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Dec. 20, 2025.

item.title: ‘Where’s the Humanity?’ Bondi Attack Leaves Suspects’ Neighborhood Stunned
item.description: The alleged gunmen in the shooting, Sajid Akram, 50 and his son, Naveed Akram, 24, were from Bonnyrigg, a diverse, multilingual suburb miles from Sydney’s Bondi Beach.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka, Max Kim and Matthew Abbott

media:content.media:description: A pedestrian overpass spanning a main road on Friday in Bonnyrigg, a multicultural suburb of Sydney.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Palo Alto Confronts Billionaires Who Hog Its Housing Stock
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 20, 2025.

item.title: Epstein Files Timeline: How the Trump Administration Released Records
item.description: A year of political pressure and partial disclosures preceded the release of long-sought records on Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump has faced persistent scrutiny over his shifting stance on the release of Justice Department files related to Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: 6 Takeaways From the First Batch of the Epstein Files
item.description: Many of the Justice Department documents were heavily redacted, and President Trump’s name was rarely mentioned. The White House also sought to make political hay of the release of photos of Bill Clinton.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer

item.title: Io or Luna
item.description: Robert S. Gard’s second Saturday puzzle is as bright as two moons.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Lovinger

media:content.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Muses parade in New Orleans during Mardi Gras in 2006.

item.title: Epstein Victims Upset About Lack of Transparency in Newly Released Files
item.description: Several victims said they were frustrated by the heavy redactions of photos and documents that the Justice Department released on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein and Mike Baker

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Survivors spoke during a news conference on the Epstein Files Transparency Act ahead of the House vote to release the files in November.

item.title: Judge Blocks Trump Administration’s Homeless Aid Plan
item.description: The proposal would have required recipients to get treatment for addiction or mental illness as a condition of receiving housing funds. The administration has said it will try again.
item.dc:creator: Jason DeParle

media:content.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Geffner House, in Manhattan, provides permanent housing to low-income adults, many of whom were previously homeless.

item.title: Vivek Ramaswamy Challenges Conservatives on Surging Anti-Indian Hate
item.description: The leading Republican candidate for Ohio governor is calling out his party for rising intolerance, including against Indian American immigrants and their children, like him.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra

media:content.media:credit: Jon Cherry/Associated Press

item.title: White House Chides Smithsonian for Delayed Turnover of Records on Programming
item.description: The institution has tried to work with the administration’s demands that it present a more uplifting view of American history.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Smithsonian Castle, home of the Smithsonian Institution administrative offices and information center, in August.

item.title: Rubio Meets (and Meets, and Meets … ) the Press
item.description: The secretary of state held a marathon news conference, offering little news but more respect for reporters than most others in the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley

media:content.media:credit: Kevin Mohatt/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio fielded questions from reporters for more than two hours on Friday.

item.title: Lawmakers Criticize Justice Dept. For Not Releasing All Epstein Files
item.description: Republicans and Democrats who had been pressing for the disclosure accused officials of failing to comply with a law that requires all material to be released.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Senator Chuck Schumer, the minority leader, said, “Simply releasing a mountain of blacked out pages violates the spirit of transparency and the letter of the law.”

item.title: Hochul Repeals Rule Allowing New Customers Free Gas Hookups
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul struck down a decades-old provision that raised gas bills for millions of New Yorkers. The move could help curb the use of fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Hilary Howard

media:content.media:credit: Cindy Schultz for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gov. Kathy Hochul’s repeal of a rule that allowed for free gas hookups for some new customers was applauded by climate activists and other supporters.

item.title: Greg Biffle’s Plane Turned Back Minutes After Takeoff
item.description: The National Transportation Safety Board is investigating the crash at a North Carolina airport, which killed seven people, including the driver Greg Biffle and his wife and children.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.category: National Assn of Stock Car Auto Racing

media:content.media:credit: Matt Kelley/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Emergency vehicles responding to the plane crash that killed the star NASCAR driver Greg Biffle, his family and three others at a regional airport in Statesville, N.C., on Thursday.

item.title: Elise Stefanik Tried Everything to Please Trump. He Still Jilted Her.
item.description: The G.O.P. congresswoman who ran as a moderate but became an “ultra MAGA” Trump acolyte ultimately found herself undermined by the president and politically adrift.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Elise Stefanik’s tumble from grace crystallized the limits of MAGA loyalty and the risks of building a political identity around President Trump.

item.title: Hochul Reaches Deal on A.I. Regulation in New York
item.description: The bill, which lawmakers passed in June, will be modified to more closely match a similar law in California, at Big Tech’s urging.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes

media:content.media:credit: Kent J. Edwards for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gov. Kathy Hochul at Grand Central Terminal in December.

item.title: Immigration Officials Deport Queens 6-Year-Old and Father Who Fled China
item.description: Hundreds of people had rallied for the family in New York City after they were separated by Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents in November.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ley and Hamed Aleaziz

item.title: Epstein Files Include 1996 Child Porn Complaint That F.B.I. Ignored
item.description: Newly released files show how Maria Farmer, who worked for Mr. Epstein in the 1990s, had urged the F.B.I. to investigate him. The case went nowhere for years.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker and Matthew Goldstein

media:content.media:credit: Andrea Morales for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Maria Farmer in 2019.

item.title: Justice Dept. Will Appeal Dismissal of Comey and James Indictments
item.description: The Trump administration had vowed to fight a judge’s decision to dismiss unrelated criminal charges against James Comey, the former F.B.I. director, and Letitia James, the attorney general of New York.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett and Jonah E. Bromwich

media:content.media:credit: William B. Plowman/NBCUniversal, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: A federal judge last month dismissed the criminal case against James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, on the grounds that Lindsey Halligan had been unlawfully appointed to a top prosecutor position.

item.title: Trump Is Rarely Mentioned in New Epstein Files
item.description: The files that The Times initially reviewed on Friday included only a handful of references to or images of Mr. Trump.
item.dc:creator: David Enrich

item.title: Trump Picks New Leader for Southern Command as Venezuela Pressure Grows
item.description: Lt. Gen. Francis L. Donovan, a Marine general with expansive experience in special operations and the Middle East, would take over after the abrupt departure of the previous commander.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )

media:content.media:credit: U.S. Marine Corps
media:content.media:description: If confirmed by the Senate, Lt. Gen. Francis L. Donovan would take over as boat strikes in the Caribbean and Pacific have come under sharp criticism from lawmakers from both parties.

item.title: The Justice Dept. Released a Trove of Epstein Files
item.description: Also, investigators seek a motive in killings at Brown and M.I.T. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

item.title: Suspect in Brown and M.I.T. Killings Died 2 Days Before He Was Found, Autopsy Shows
item.description: The examination confirmed that the suspect had died from a self-inflicted gunshot wound. His body was found late Thursday in a storage unit in New Hampshire.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla

media:content.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The suspect’s body was found in a storage facility in Salem, N.H., late Thursday.

item.title: Bill Clinton Features Prominently in Epstein Files Release
item.description: The focus on a former president comes at a moment when Republicans have fought to shift public attention away from Mr. Epstein’s friendship with President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Confessore, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Katie Benner

item.title: Introducing Your Next Newsletter Writer (for Now), and Looking Back at 2025
item.description: There will be much to dive into when On Politics returns in January, and a familiar voice will be taking the helm — at least for a little while.
item.dc:creator: Jess Bidgood

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump at his inauguration.

item.title: Allan Ludwig, ‘Founding Father’ of Gravestone Studies, Dies at 92
item.description: His Pulitzer-nominated book “Graven Images” inspired a reassessment of Puritan art, challenging the belief that imagery carved on headstones was meaningless.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman

item.title: Kennedy Center, Memorial to JFK, Is Trump’s Now, Too
item.description: The Kennedy Center installed President Trump’s name on the facade of the arts center, which had been designated as a living memorial to President John F. Kennedy.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Crew members unveiling the new name of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts on Friday morning.

item.title: Emily Korzenik, Rabbi Who Took a Bar Mitzvah to Poland, Dies at 96
item.description: Part of the first generation of women ordained in America, she presided over the first bar mitzvah in Krakow, still scarred by the Holocaust, in decades. It did not go smoothly.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

media:content.media:credit: Thomas McDonald for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Rabbi Emily Faust Korzenik in Stamford, Conn., in 2003. For 25 years she presided over the Fellowship for Jewish Learning, a congregation there.

item.title: ICE Detainee Dies After Being Held at a Troubled Jailhouse in Newark
item.description: Jean Wilson Brutus, 41, was one of four migrants to die in the past week after medical emergencies in detention centers in New Jersey, Michigan, Mississippi and Pennsylvania.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully and Luis Ferré-Sadurní

media:content.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: At the Delaney Hall detention center in Newark, where visitors regularly gather outside, a detainee from Haiti died soon after arriving last week.

item.title: Bachata Is Still Underrated
item.description: Romeo Santos and Prince Royce, the leading stars of Dominican bachata music, explain why the genre deserves respect and to be platformed.

item.title: Mamdani Revamps Hiring After Old Antisemitic Remarks Prompt Aide to Quit
item.description: Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani said he did not know about the antisemitic posts and would not have hired the woman who made them if he had.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays

media:content.media:credit: Heather Khalifa for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Catherine Almonte Da Costa, left, resigned a day after Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani appointed her to oversee administration hiring.

item.title: Elon Musk’s 2018 Tesla Pay Deal Is Restored by Delaware Supreme Court
item.description: A state judge had invalidated the package, saying shareholders were not properly informed about it. Friday’s ruling cleared the plan, now worth $139 billion.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner, Peter Eavis and Rebecca F. Elliott

media:content.media:credit: Evan Vucci/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Elon Musk had appealed a ruling by a Delaware judge who rejected Tesla’s pay package last year.

item.title: U.S. Strikes Islamic State Targets in Syria
item.description: American forces struck dozens of suspected ISIS sites, making good on President Trump’s vow to avenge two American soldiers and a civilian U.S. interpreter killed by the group last week.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The dignified transfer of the American soldiers killed in Syria. The assault last weekend was a stark reminder of the danger in the region and the quandary of whether to keep American forces there at all.

item.title: N.B.A. Tweaks Its Rules to Thwart Sports Betting Cheats
item.description: The basketball league will require teams to submit injury reports closer to tipoff, an attempt to close one source of inside information.
item.dc:creator: Tania Ganguli

media:content.media:credit: Kirby Lee/Imagn Images, via Reuters Connect
media:content.media:description: N.B.A. commissioner Adam Silver said this week that “we’re going to have to do whatever is necessary to protect our integrity.”

item.title: Trump’s Name Joins Kennedy’s on Performing Arts Center’s Facade
item.description: Workers hauled up large letters spelling out Mr. Trump’s full name to add to the white marble face of the building on Friday morning.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh and Chris Cameron
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump’s name was added to the facade of the John F. Kennedy Memorial Center for the Performing Arts in Washington on Friday.

item.title: How to See the Epstein Files Released on Friday
item.description: The searchable database published by the Justice Department is broken into multiple categories.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold

item.title: Toss a Coin in the Trevi Fountain? That’ll Be 2 Euros, Wish Not Included
item.description: Starting on Feb. 1, Rome will charge tourists a fee to go down into the basin of the famed 18th-century fountain. Not every one is happy (except Romans, who won’t have to pay).
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo

media:content.media:credit: Andrew Medichini/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Visitors admiring the Trevi Fountain in Rome, on Friday. The small square around it is often densely packed.

item.title: How The Times is covering the latest release of Epstein files.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Hochul Expected to Veto Bill Requiring 2-Person Crews on Subway Trains
item.description: The bill, which would ensure that every train has a conductor and a driver, as most now do, was supported by the transit workers’ union and opposed by many transit advocates.
item.dc:creator: Stefanos Chen

media:content.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A conductor on an A train in Manhattan in March, 2024.

item.title: R.F.K. Jr. Likely to Swap U.S. Childhood Vaccine Schedule for Denmark’s
item.description: The shift would mean fewer shots recommended for children. But a Danish health official found the idea baffling, saying the United States was getting “crazier and crazier in public health.”
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

media:content.media:credit: Fabian Sommer/picture alliance, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: A pediatrician administering a combination six-way vaccination against diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, poliomyelitis, Haemophilus influenzae type b and hepatitis B, in Berlin.

item.title: Elise Stefanik Drops Out of N.Y. Governor’s Race and Will Leave Congress
item.description: Ms. Stefanik, a Republican congresswoman and staunch ally of President Trump, abruptly ended her bid to unseat Gov. Kathy Hochul and said she would not seek another House term.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Representative Elise Stefanik is one of President Trump’s most steadfast supporters, but he had shied away from endorsing her in the New York governor’s race.

item.title: Even Its Author Is Shocked by How Fans Have Embraced “Heated Rivalry,” the Gay Hockey Romance Series
item.description: Thanks to a steamy television adaptation, Rachel Reid’s romance novels about closeted hockey players have become mainstream best-sellers.
item.dc:creator: Angelina Mazza

media:content.media:credit: Carolina Andrade for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: “It’s been surreal,” says Rachel Reid, the author of the Game Changer romance series, outside her Nova Scotia home.

item.title: Controversial Dakota Pipeline Gets a Big, Belated Government Boost
item.description: A delayed environmental review cleared the Dakota Access Pipeline to continue operating. Separately, a North Dakota judge expressed unusual exasperation over the tangled legal battles.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick

media:content.media:credit: Thibaud Moritz/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Activists in France earlier this year supporting Greenpeace, which is fighting a verdict against it that could bankrupt its U.S. operations.

item.title: Epstein Release Reveals New Photos but Many Files Are Withheld
item.description: The material includes thousands of documents and hundreds of images related to Jeffrey Epstein. But the Justice Department held back thousands more files despite a law requiring their disclosure by Friday.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
